title: Derive GitLab Employee badge from gitlab-com group
description:
### Summary

Currently, we determine if a user is a GitLab employee by checking the domain of the user's primary email.

This approach has a couple of problems, viz:

- Not all GitLab employees use GitLab email as their primary email
- There has been incidents in the past wherein non-GitLab employee were able to set their email with a gitlab.com domain
- There is no easy way to query

### Proposal

One way to circumvent this problem, is to check if the user belongs to the `gitlab-com` group.

A more scalable option will be introduce concept of Employee-Organization model.

Refer to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28837#note_328910484 for detailed discussion.

epic.title: GitLab Team Member badges

title: Add visibility and last updated information to the Image Repository Detail View
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API. When users have to navigate a large number of image repositories, information such as repository visibility and when a tag was last published helps users determine the health of the repository. Currently, it is difficult to gather that information.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Improve the experience of understanding data related to an image repository, specifically allowing users to quickly understand how recently the image repository was updated as well as the visibility of that project.

### Proposal

Add an `eye` icon for an image repository belonging to a public project and include high-level information about when this image repository was last updated.

| Image Repository delete button |
|---|
| ![Add_last_published_and_visibility](/uploads/d5c0b7b867ce368c192c2c6d146d1775/Add_last_published_and_visibility.png) |

### Further details

The `eye` icon should be used when an image repository is associated with a public project. The `eye-slash` icon should be used for image repositories associated with a private project or group.

title: Add a graphql endpoint for package registry
description:
As a part of enabling better handoff of the work between ~frontend and ~backend, during the development and enhancement of our features we should strive to move our development effort from the REST API to a GRAPHQL api.

As the first step in this direction we should build a new endpoint/resource for the gitlab packages.

REST API for reference:

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/packages.html

title: Alert detail views on mobile
description:

title: Deactivate mirrors that do not have the correct license
description:
## Background

We used to offer pull mirroring for free to private projects on GitLab.com. We stopped doing that in March 2020: https://about.gitlab.com/releases/2020/03/12/free-period-for-cicd-external-repositories/

When we did that, we ran into performance issues with the sheer number of free private mirrors we were loading into memory, only to reject: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212074

We addressed this by checking the plan in the query, and only searching for mirrors that are either:

1. On paid plans.
2. On public projects. (As public projects get Gold features for free.) - this is no [longer valid](https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2022/02/04/ultimate-perks-for-open-source-projects/) as of 2022-02-17 for new projects and 2022-07-01 for all free public projects.

## Problem

This query got slower over time, because the database still had to inspect all of the 'old' pull mirrors: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216252

This is because we search for all pull mirrors and put them in order where the one that was updated least frequently is first. As all the free private pull mirrors stopped being processed in March, they were always at the front of this set, and the query performance degraded.

This query is listed as a top 50 queries by total time in https://console.postgres.ai/gitlab/gitlab_production/reports/425/files/113266/md#postgres-checkup_K003

This performance issue was explored in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325503.

### Workaround

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216252#note_334514544 describes a hacky workaround where we make sure that we only look for mirrors that are supposed to be next mirrored after we disabled free pull mirroring. This buys us some time, but has its own problems.

### New problems

1. If a user had a free private pull mirror that was due to be updated before 2020-03-28, and then either make the project public or pay for a plan, it won't resume automatically. They will need to [force an update](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/repository_mirroring.html#forcing-an-update-core).
2. The query was already complex, and now it has an extra wrinkle specifically for GitLab.com.

## Proposal

Somehow mark these mirrors as inactive, in such a way that:

1. It's cheap to do. (Maybe just a migration that only runs for GitLab.com?)
2. It's easy for a user to restart their mirror.

Then we can remove all of the block inside `if check_mirror_plans_in_query?` in `UpdateAllMirrorsWorker#pull_mirrors_batch`, making the query much simpler and easier to reason about.

We can also remove the part of `UpdateAllMirrorsWorker#schedule_mirrors!` that links to this issue in a comment.

title: Add image repository level delete functionality to the Image Repository detail view
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API. 

When handling large numbers of image repositories, it is not uncommon for users to want to delete the image repository after viewing the details. Currently, this requires unique navigation back to the list view to delete the image repository, which can cause a loss of context for users.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Improve the delete image repository experience by allowing users to delete an image repository while currently viewing the details.

### Proposal

Add a delete image repository button to the UI. A confirmation model will pop up. After confirming, the image repository will enter a disabled "Repository is being deleted". 

| Image Repository delete button |
|---|
| ![Add_delete_button_to_image_repository_list_view](/uploads/427dc90ec12221a6a8cb7295d1be8516/Add_delete_button_to_image_repository_list_view.png) |

| Image repository has been marked for deletion |
|---|
| ![Add_alert_saying_the_registry_has_been_marked_for_deltion](/uploads/50d3ff75c4c65b0269d229d2618506e2/Add_alert_saying_the_registry_has_been_marked_for_deltion.png) |

##### FINAL COPY

Alert/Banner

Title: `Image repository will be deleted` (unchanged)

Body: `This image repository will be deleted. Learn more. (link)`

### Confirmation Modal

Title: `Delete image repository?`

Body: `Deleting the image repository will delete all images and tags inside. This action cannot be undone.`

Buttons: `Confirm` and `Cancel`

### Further details

I have included a post-deletion state including an alert saying that this image repository was marked for deletion. It is assumed that the user will need to confirm the delete action before returning to this screen.  The image repository list view should also appear disabled. 

The MVC does not include a way to "un-delete" the image repository. This is something we may need to consider.

title: Add sorting component to the image repository list view of the Container Registry UI
description:

However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API. 

As the number of image repositories grow, users can't currently sort the list which limits their ability to find specific image repositories.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Improve the experience of users searching for a specific image repository by showing how the image repositories are currently ordered and offer the ability to change that.

### Proposal

Add a sort component to the image repository list view to allow users to sort the list.

| Image Repository List with Sort |
|---|
| ![Add_sorting_component](/uploads/b42205373f55b5a0c3ae98df889e3de2/Add_sorting_component.png) |

### Further details

The options for sorting are currently limited.  The primary "win" for adding this component is making it clear to the users how the list is currently sorted and allow them to flip the order. As we create a more robust metadata database, we can include a larger variety of ways to sort.

However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API. Each image repository has any number of individual tags. Currently, there is no way to tell how many tags an image repository has without viewing the details.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)

### User experience goal

Improve the experience of browsing image repositories by adding the tag count of an image repository to the list view.

title: Convert the Image Repository view from a table to a list view
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API.

As the total number of image repositories grows, the current UI pattern becomes cumbersome to users. This intensifies as sorting and filtering mechanics are introduced into the UI.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Improve the experience of browsing image repositories by creating a list view to bring the container registry into parody with the rest of the product.

### Proposal

Convert the current user interface to a list-view component. 

| Image Repository List view w/ List component |
|---|
| ![Convert_Image_Repositories_to_list_view](/uploads/770a07cf2a2c082f458646c534bcc311/Convert_Image_Repositories_to_list_view.png) |

### Further details

n/a

title: Improve the Container Registry UI Header Section with relevant metadata
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The Package stage allows you to publish, consume, and discover images, all in one place. Users publish and pull images using GitLab CI/CD, the command line, or the GitLab API.

The problem this issue is devoted to solving is updating the header section of the Container Registry UI to provide high-level information regarding this specific registry.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

This update will improve the experience by providing high-level information at the start of the interface instead of requiring users to infer the data. This becomes especially important when the number of total image repositories requires pagination.


### Proposal

Update the header section of the Container Registry UI to include the number of image repositories contained in this registry and details of the expiration policy.

| Container Registry UI Header Section |
|---|
| ![Update_Header_Information](/uploads/bfd4fc01c2ab9807d3e4fbd0696c8f27/Update_Header_Information.png) |

### Further details

Open Question: 

- When a container registry does not have expiration policies enabled, should we remove the expiration policy moment entirely, or add copy saying "expiration policies disabled"

Other Notes: 

- I'm suggesting we update the copy in the header section.  In testing, users really appreciated the direct link to the documentation. I am suggesting we remove the references to Docker.
- I have updated the `Quick Start` wording to `CLI Commands` as per this UXR Insight: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/uxr_insights/-/issues/1094

title: Organize package models by package type
description:
## Summary

* Package models are all living under the `Packages::` namespace
* This leads to a mix of models that deals with different package types to be at the same level. Examples:
  * `Packages::MavenMetadatum`
  * `Packages::ConanFileMetadatum`
  * `Packages::PypiMetadatum`

-> We should apply the same strategy as we have in the package services: each type has its own and dedicated namespace.

## Improvements

* Improve code organization. `Packages::` will not be a bag of everything mashed together. It will contain common/shared classes among all package types
* Improve code readability

## Risks

* Models are linked to database tables (Example: `Packages::MavenMetadatum` linked to `packages_maven_metadata`). We want to avoid a table renaming so we must use the exact same terms and in the same order (Example: `Packages::MavenMetadatum` can only be transformed into `Packages::Maven::Metadatum` and not something else such as `Packages::Metadatum::Maven`)

## Involved components

* `Packages::ConanFileMetadatum`
* `Packages::ConanMetadatum`
* `Packages::MavenMetadatum`
* `Packages::PypiMetadatum`

## Optional: Intended side effects

* Future package type metadata will have their own namespace at the model level too.

title: Refactor diff views to decouple inline and side by side
description:
## Summary

Currently inline and side by side diff views both use `diff_table_cell` and `diff_gutter_avatars`. There is some logic written to shoehorn these different states into the same HTML. Breaking `diff_table_cell` out into two components will simplify this logic an allow us to remove an event watcher that causes the page to be laggy during hover effects.

Removing that lag is a prereq for multiline commenting.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/14128

### Fancy mermaid diagrams

#### Current layout

```mermaid
classDiagram
  diff_content <|-- inline_diff_view
  diff_content <|-- parallel_diff_view
  inline_diff_view <|-- inline_diff_table_row
  parallel_diff_view <|-- parallel_diff_table_row
  inline_diff_table_row <|-- diff_table_cell
  parallel_diff_table_row <|-- diff_table_cell
  diff_table_cell <|-- diff_gutter_avatars
```

#### Proposed layout

```mermaid
classDiagram
  diff_content <|-- inline_diff_view
  diff_content <|-- parallel_diff_view
  inline_diff_view <|-- inline_diff_table_row
  parallel_diff_view <|-- parallel_diff_table_row
  inline_diff_table_row <|-- inline_diff_table_cell
  parallel_diff_table_row <|-- parallel_diff_table_cell
  inline_diff_table_cell <|-- diff_gutter_avatars
  parallel_diff_table_cell <|-- diff_gutter_avatars
```

## Improvements

Performance boost for hover states over `*_diff_table_row`
Simple logic for rendering.

## Risks

Most of the refactored code involves displaying user avatars and comment buttons. The biggest concern is that altering this code could cause comments/discussions to stop working. Either discussions will not be displayed properly or the ability to comment could be broken.

To mitigate we will only refactor one "side" at a time. i.e. just the inline view, then the parallel view. This is possible because new components have to be built for the refactoring. Also, the logic for the shared components is localized to those components. So this could potentially be feature flagged, or at the very least easy to roll back.

## Involved components

Base path: `app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components`

- diff_content
- inline_diff_view
- parallel_diff_view
- inline_diff_table_row
- parallel_diff_table_row
- diff_table_cell
- diff_gutter_avatars

title: Investigate usage of Wappalyzer
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Trytodefinethewho/what/whyoftheopportunityasauserstory.Forexample,"Asa(who),Iwant(what),soIcan(why/value)." -->
One of the current pain points with DAST testing is not being able to configure the scan to ignore specific technologies that are not being used in the site. One way we can mitigate this pain point is by automatically detecting the technologies using (Wappalyzer)[https://www.zaproxy.org/docs/desktop/addons/technology-detection/].
### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)

title: SCIM does not allow a new user to sign in via SAML without local sign in
description:
Apparently SCIM and SAML used to allow a SCIM-created user to sign in with SAML without first signing in with a GitLab.com local/existing account. For example, if a user had never used gitlab.com before, but SCIM created them a user, the user could sign in via SSO and that's the only authentication they would require. 

Now that `scim_identities` has been enabled, it seems this flow is broken. Here's what it looks like:

1. SCIM creates the user and the `scim_identities`. 
2. User visits the group SAML SSO sign in page and clicks 'Sign in with Single Sign-On' button.
3. User gets redirected to the SAML provider to sign in. 
4. On redirect, user is sent to the regular GitLab sign in page with a message that they must sign in or sign up to link their account.

## Workaround

1. Have user reset their password.
1. Follow [existing user linking flow](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/saml_sso/scim_setup.html#user-access-and-linking-setup).

title: "Cmd+Enter" when leaving a comment fails to clear the locally-saved comment text
description:
### Summary

When I press cmd+enter to submit a comment in an issue/MR discussion, the text of that comment reappears the next time I go to leave a comment.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Start a new discussion thread
1. In the discussion thread, compose a comment, then **click "Comment"**.
1. Click in the text box to start composing another comment. Notice that it is empty.
1. Compose a second comment, then **type cmd+enter**.
1. Click in the text box to start composing another comment. Notice that your previous comment is still in the text entry box.

Note that this only seems to happen in threads, and only within a single thread.

### Example Project

This occurs on any project (see screen recording below for an example). An example project link isn't too helpful here, since the bug depends on the user's browser state, not just the server-side project state.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The previously-entered comment in a thread still appears.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The text entry box should be empty.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Recording_2020-05-05_at_3.21.42_PM](/uploads/855757c35ee14a3ccf9adc11f8e49cd8/Screen_Recording_2020-05-05_at_3.21.42_PM.mov)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: To-Do: Capture timestamp of resolution
description:
### Problem to solve

To-Dos can be marked as "Done" and, after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215046, also as "Dismissed".  These states are considered a To-Do's "resolved" states.  But how long did it take a To-Do to be resolved?  And what was the average time it took a collection of To-Dos to be resolved?

### Intended users

See the [intended users described by the epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3061#intended-users).

### Proposal

To-Dos have a `resolved_at` attribute that is set when a To-Do is resolved (marked as "Done" or "Dismissed").  This attribute is un-set if a To-Do is un-resolved (marked "Pending" by an "Undo" action of some kind).

### Out of scope

A backfill migration to update historical records is out of scope.

### Further details

- This idea [came from @pshutsin](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216045#note_336785544).
- This will provide the foundation for a future iteration to display data about resolution time.

title: Forbid calls with potential to take long sleeps
description:
@ashmckenzie proposed adding `SleepingLock::MAX_ATTEMPTS`:

- [ ] @ashmckenzie started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30654#note_336656597):  (+2 comments)

    > Should we set a default for `max_attempts`? e.g.
    > 
    > ```suggestion:-0+0
    >       def obtain(max_attempts = 10)
    > ```
    > 
    > And possibly create a constant of `MAX_ATTEMPTS = 10`
    > 
    > Thoughts?

This is a good idea - we should add an upper bound on the number of times we are prepared to wait/length of sleep we are prepared to make, and either enforce these silently (`[attempts, MAX_ATTEMTPS].max`, etc) or raise errors.

What we want to do is avoid waiting on a lock for a long time since this ties up ruby threads, which are a scarce resource, and waiting on a lock is not a good use of them. We should therefore make it impossible to call `obtain` in such a way that we might wait for an excessive amount of time.

title: Geo: Preliminary research on what is needed for PostgreSQL 12
description:
### Background

There was some conversation in the `#gdk` channel about using PG12 with Geo. The discussion started, because Ubuntu 20.04 ships with PG12, see the GDK issue for context: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-development-kit/-/issues/682#note_335540308

One change in PG12 might be relevant/important for Geo (from the release notes):

>>>
Move `recovery.conf` settings into [`postgresql.conf`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/runtime-config-wal.html#RUNTIME-CONFIG-WAL-ARCHIVE-RECOVERY) (Masao Fujii, Simon Riggs, Abhijit Menon-Sen, Sergei Kornilov)

`recovery.conf` is no longer used, and the server will not start if that file exists. [`recovery.signal`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/runtime-config-wal.html#RUNTIME-CONFIG-WAL-ARCHIVE-RECOVERY) and `standby.signal` files are now used to switch into non-primary mode. The `trigger_file` setting has been renamed to [`promote_trigger_file`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/runtime-config-replication.html#GUC-PROMOTE-TRIGGER-FILE). The `standby_mode` setting has been removed.
>>>

`@eread` was testing Geo on GDK and PG12 a little while ago, but he ran into this issue: https://pgstef.github.io/2018/11/26/postgresql12_preview_recovery_conf_disappears.html

The article dates back from back from before PG12 was released, so some info might be incorrect. But still, there might a problem.

### Impact on GDK

It's not clear to me what is wrong with PG12 on GDK. I guess we should set it up, and see what happens. I'm hopeful we can fix it with minimal changes.

### Impact on omnibus

This is even less clear. `@stanhu` thought `recovery.conf` was used to promote a secondary, but it seems `pg_ctl promote` is used, so we should be good here

### Suggestion

We better try to make GDK work with Geo and PG12 soon, but increasingly more people will no longer be able to run PG11 on their development machines.

Also [PG12 will be landing in 13.3](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2184), so it would be nice to be ahead of the game.

title: Avoid saving Ruby UnauthenticatedAuthor object in audit_events table
description:
### Summary

When we record audit events on failed login attempt, the author was translated to an instance of Audit::UnaunthenticatedAuthor and got saved through to the `audit_events` table.

```sql
-[ RECORD 1 ]-------------------------------------------------------------------
id          | 1295
author_id   | -1
type        | SecurityEvent
entity_id   | -1
entity_type | User
details     | ---                                                               +
            | :failed_login: STANDARD                                           +
            | :author_name: dsads                                               +
            | :target_details: !ruby/object:Gitlab::Audit::UnauthenticatedAuthor+
            |   id: -1                                                          +
            |   name: dsads                                                     +
            | :ip_address: 127.0.0.1                                            +
            | :entity_path:                                                     +
            | 
created_at  | 2020-05-05 11:33:05.781195
updated_at  | 2020-05-05 11:33:05.781195
```

This causes some undesirable consequences:

- Coupling between data store and application code (i.e. changing `UnauthenticatedAuthor` class name will break Audit Events service)
- Incorrect presentation on UI
![Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_9.51.05_pm](/uploads/70927a456691072c7f7c2aca6c7e595a/Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_9.51.05_pm.png)

### Steps to reproduce

* Navigate to the login page (i.e. `http://localhost:3000/users/sign_in`)
* Enter an incorrect username and password
* Login as an admin and navigate to Admin Area > Monitoring > Audit Log

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

We should only save primitive types in serialized hash.

### Possible fixes

- Fix writing of `failed_login` audit event to avoid persisting Ruby object
- Include DB data migrations to fix historical records

title: Pull mirroring with SSH key auth shows Last Successful Update time and error badge
description:
### Summary

When pull mirroring is set up with authentication via `SSH public key`, the initial automatic update attempt fails, but the `last successful update` column shows a time *and* there's an error badge.

This makes it seem as if it failed and succeeded. It's not clear what the user should do when they see that mirroring has not occurred.

This caused an end-to-end test to fail: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216297 (it passed before https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30157)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Configure pull mirroring with SSH key.
1. Wait for the initial update to occur automatically.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/mlapierre-test/pull-mirror-target

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The UI shows an error badge but the `last successful update` column also has a value.

![pull_mirror2](/uploads/b3aeec84a0894db4a6ee81680d2df8fa/pull_mirror2.png)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The `last successful update` column value is `Never`.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

/cc @patrickbajao

title: Pull mirroring with SSH key auth always fails the initial automatic update attempt
description:
### Summary

If pull mirroring is set up with authentication via `SSH public key`, the initial automatic update attempt will fail because the attempt is made before new key can be copied to the mirror source.

This caused an end-to-end test to fail: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216297

This was not an issue before https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30157 because it was possible to immediately update mirroring after copying the key to the source, so the error could be ignored (although it still wasn't ideal).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Configure pull mirroring with SSH key.
2. Wait for the initial update to occur automatically.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/mlapierre-test/pull-mirror-target

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The update fails (on GitLab.com)

![pull_mirror2](/uploads/637c21fd3fe227d9807a68f86d4cec7d/pull_mirror2.png)

It doesn't seem as if the host key is the problem because it also fails when the host key is present (on GDK):

![pull_mirror3](/uploads/5c0243cdd75fa16c77901fac1157137f/pull_mirror3.png)

And it succeeds when the SSH key is added to the source as a deploy key:

![pull_mirror4](/uploads/cc3a42be2f8a7c5b6ac60c922e6c24c8/pull_mirror4.png)

(from another test project: https://gitlab.com/mlapierre-test/pull-mirror-target2)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Perhaps display a message that the update will succeed once the SSH key is available on the source. (And make the error badge and `last successful update` time consistent - I'll open another issue for that).

AND/OR

Allow the user to manually update once after they have copied the key to the mirror source, but don't make them wait five minutes because of the failed automatic update attempt.

/cc @patrickbajao

title: Documentation: Clarify Deploy Keys behavior, security risks and trouble shooting
description:
### Problem

GitLab's [Deploy Keys](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ssh/#deploy-keys) exists for ages, however, the documentation is very poor thus we (Devs, Security folks, users and customers) are having hard time to understand how it behaves and what result is expected. We should update the documentation before we've decided a technical approach for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30769.

For the reference, GitHub's [Deploy Key](https://developer.github.com/v3/guides/managing-deploy-keys/#deploy-keys) is much clearer than ours.

### Things should be documented

- Overview
- When it should be used (or Pro/Con)
  - Security Risks
- Permission
  - "Allow write access" gives write access to the key.
  - The owner of the deploy key is evaluated to [our permission model](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html#project-members-permissions), which takes the precedence over "Allow write access" option.
  - The owner of the deploy key is set to the pipeline triggerer. 
  - If the owner doesn't have access to a [Protected branches](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/protected_branches.html), his deploy key cannot access neither. 
  - If the owner doesn't have access to a [Protected environments](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/protected_environments.html), the pipeline triggered by his deploy key cannot access neither. 
- Tips
  - Create [a bot user](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30769#note_227430503) as a virtual machine user
- Troubleshooting
  - Deploy Key cannot push to a protected branch

title: Investigate adding support for RubyGems to the GitLab Package Registry
description:
### Release post
If you are a GitLab user building a Rails app, you need to be able to publish your gems to a private repository, share them and install them from a safe location. Why not use your GitLab project? You are already storing your code there and you are probably using GitLab CI. It's easy to publish and install packages using your pipeline. In fact, if you are using GitLab CI/CD to publish and update your gems, you can easily find the pipeline, commit and branch responsible for updating that gem. Authentication is easy. Simply use your personal access token. With support for job and deploy tokens coming soon. 

### Problem to solve
As part of our goal to build a product that in 3 years will allow 90% of our customers to use GitLab for all of their package management needs, we must add support for common package manager formats, such as RubyGems. Prior to adding support for a given package manager, we need to have a task of investigation of documentation, API endpoints, and other implementation requirements. 

This issue is intended to detail the requirements for the RubyGems Repository MVC and link to issues outside the scope of the MVC. It will be considered complete when the product developers have broken down the MVC into sub-issues and added them to the [RubyGems Repository epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3200).

### Proposal 
Investigate adding RubyGems support to the GitLab Package Registry. Based on that investigation, identify a reasonable MVC that can be delivered in 1-2 milestones.
- Create, size and schedule a list of sub-issues and add them to the [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3200)

#### Scope of MVC
1. Use your GitLab project as a RubyGems remote
1. Authenticate with your GitLab personal access token
1. Publish gems to your project
1. Install gems from your project
1. Measure `push_package` and `pull_package` events on GitLab.com using Snowplow

#### Beyond the MVC
1. Measure usage with the usage ping
1. The Package Registry UI supports RubyGems, including install and setup commands, build and package specific metadata.
1. Authenticate with a job, deploy, or project access token.
1. Create a `.gitlab-ci.yml` template to make getting started easy.
1. Begin dogfooding the registry 
1. Starting in RubyGems 2.0, a Specification can hold arbitrary metadata. We should consider supporting arbitrary metadata.

#### Metadata

Metadata will need to be extracted, similar to how we handle NuGet. For the MVC we will extract the following fields:

- authors=
- files
- name
- summary
- version
- description
- email
- homepage
- license=
- licenses=
- metadata


After the MVC, we'll add:
-  add_development_dependency
-  add_runtime_dependency
-  author=
-  bindir
-  cert_chain
-  executables
-  extensions
-  extra_rdoc_files
-  platform=
-  post_install_message
-  rdoc_options
-  require_paths=
-  required_ruby_version
-  required_ruby_version=
-  required_rubygems_version
-  required_rubygems_version=
-  requirements
-  rubygems_version
-  signing_key

### Permissions and Security
The permissions should follow the same levels as all other package registries

### Links / references
- http://docs.seattlerb.org/rubygems/
- https://guides.rubygems.org/rubygems-org-rate-limits/
- https://guides.rubygems.org/specification-reference/

epic.title: Make the RubyGems Repository  generally available (GA)

title: Use DAST Scan profiles from database
description:
### Problem to solve

To simplify the configuration of DAST for customers, customers can create scan and site profiles in "on-demand" scans. Today, they can then run a DAST scan through the web interface using those scan and site profiles. This eliminates the need for the user to configure or create a YAML file. 

However, if customers want to run a scan in their pipeline they have to configure all variables in their YAML file. There is no way they can leverage the profiles they created in the web interface. 

### Proposal

GitLab introduces new job-level keyword to `.gitlab-ci.yml` called `dast_configuration`:

```yaml
dast:
  stage: dast
  dast_configuration:
    site_profile: "site-profile-name"
    scanner_profile: "scanner-profile-name"
  script:
   - echo
```

Customers set the value of `dast:variables` to include the names of the profiles that they have previously saved in the database.

#### Technical details

**Note:** The developer should get a spike of this implementation into review by the CI team as quickly in the process as possible.

- [x] Refactor DAST on-demand config generation (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326953)
- [x] DAST On-Demand Scans - Add Explicit Secrets Authorization Schema (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330297)
- [x] Evaluate the `variables:` keyword and add the corresponding job variables to the job. This will probably take place in [`Gitlab::Ci::Pipeline::Seed::Build`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/98fc0227320c0379bf79d8add7915aa34395e536/lib/gitlab/ci/pipeline/seed/build.rb). Add non-secret variables from the DAST profile to attributes passed into [`Gitlab::Ci::Build::Context::Build`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f56372f52c289c75128cfa69e88640337eaa8827/lib/gitlab/ci/pipeline/seed/build.rb#L196) (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/62986)
- [x] Associate secret variables.
- [x] Throw error when profile not found (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334236)
- [x] Update ~documentation 

**Additional context:** `Gitlab::Ci::Pipeline::Seed::Build` is used in the `Gitlab::Ci::Pipeline::Chain::Seed` step of the pipeline creation process. The full chain is defined in [Ci::CreatePipelineService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f56372f52c289c75128cfa69e88640337eaa8827/app/services/ci/create_pipeline_service.rb#L19)

### Implementation Questions

1. Ensure we can handle authentication values that were saved in site profiles. 
1. The scan and site profiles will be updated with additional fields as DAST grows. Architect this so that as new fields are added to the scan and site profiles they can flow into DAST without updates.

title: Snippet slugifying breaks URL in markdown comment
description:
## Description

[In this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/7507#note_336222233), I'm trying to leave a link to the embedded snippet URL, but the slugifying is too greedy and doesn't slugs the URL :disappointed:

![Screen_Shot_2020-05-04_at_2.37.57_PM](/uploads/290364dec4d35de602740326519d2b0f/Screen_Shot_2020-05-04_at_2.37.57_PM.png)

## Proposal

I'd expect the slugifying behavior to see that I'm trying to link to a `.js` file and leave this URL alone.

---

## Testing Activity

@fjsanpedro:
* Check the reference is not replaced when the url ends with and extension

@vij:
* Test reference filter ignores snippet embed URLs

## MR Breakdown

@fjsanpedro:
* We need to check where that reference is replaced and, if the url has an extension, abort the replacement

title: Avoid duplicating events
description:
The following discussion from !26624 should be addressed:

- [ ] @stanhu started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/26624#note_335424760):  (+2 comments)

    > This method seems like it would get slower the more events that are generated for the Wiki. This query sorts all events for this project:
    > 
    > ```sql
    >  SELECT "events".* FROM "events" WHERE "events"."target_type" = $1 AND "events"."target_id" = $2 ORDER BY "events"."id" DESC LIMIT $3 /*application:test,correlation_id:372e1c7e9a84176097371f360bb96aae*/  [["target_type", "WikiPage::Meta"], ["target_id", 16], ["LIMIT", 1]]
    > ```
    > 
    > The second query would also have this issue because I think a sequential scan would be needed to find `created_at`:
    > 
    > ```sql
    > SELECT "events".* FROM "events" WHERE "events"."target_type" = $1 AND "events"."target_id" = $2 AND "events"."created_at" = $3 LIMIT $4 /*application:test,correlation_id:372e1c7e9a84176097371f360bb96aae*/  [["target_type", "WikiPage::Meta"], ["target_id", 16], ["created_at", "2020-05-03 06:27:43"], ["LIMIT", 1]]
    > ```
    > 
    > We don't have idempotency for our `events` table yet, but if we did want it, would we consider adding a column that has a fingerprint of the event message and use a uniqueness index against that?

## Proposal

Add a new column to the events table `fingerprint text(128), nullable`, that allows us to avoid adding the same event twice, when there is a reasonable way to know (git commit SHAs would make good fingerprints).

title: Project-level export report displays TWO spinners when report is generating
description:

Please read this!

The 'loading' spinner is displaying two times in line with each other

The 'loading' spinner should only display once

### Output of checks

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/defend/demos/webgoat/-/security/dashboard
* https://gitlab.com/stkerr/custom-scanner/-/security/dashboard

title: Selection Highlight Oversteps Bounds of Actual Selection  in Web IDE
description:
### Summary
When selecting text within the Web IDE, the selection indication highlight will overflow the actual selection.

This seems to occur specifically where new-line characters are involved. I haven't been able to reproduce it anywhere else thus far. 

It also seems to be a result of only some next-line content triggering this issue and other content doesn't. 
If there is an empty line following, for example, this issue doesn't not occur.

### Steps to reproduce
*These instructions are directly in the `example.js` within the [**Example Project**](#example-project)*

1. Select starting from anywhere after the beginning of a function's `{`
   - *NOTE: The function *has* to have some content directly on the following line after the `{`*
2. Drag to the beginning `{` of said function

You will notice the selection will highlight the opening `{`, however if you copy and past the selected text, it will NOT contain `{`  
You will also notice this doe NOT happen when attempting the same process if there is no content on the line following the `{`


### Example Project
https://gitlab.com/sololegends/web-ide-selection-example

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The highlighted section of your selection doesn't always match what is actually selected.

**Image example:** ![over-selection-ui-example_2020-05-04](/uploads/3b2984ba78edfffd79ce69a96a6dc212/over-selection-ui-example_2020-05-04.PNG)

If you copy the selected text in the image, it will **NOT** select the beginning `{`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
The visually represented selected text should *always* reflect the actuall selection being made as to not confuse the user to require extra mental processing to work out what is happening on screen.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
No logs, see image above 

### Output of checks
This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes
I haven't had time to go throught he IDE code for this issue yet unfortunately.

title: Publish Releases without giving access to source code
description:
### Release notes Previously, releases for public projects also allow access to the source code. With this update, you can now publish releases without giving access to the source code to users. This is useful for organizations that use releases as a way to give access to new versions of software but do not want the source code to be public. ### Problem to solve It's not uncommon for projects to be closed source (no public access to the source code) but publish some kind of compiled asset to the public (e.g. an `.exe` or a `.dmg`). At the moment, GitLab does not support this use case. Current options are: 1. Private projects, which requires that users who need to access the release assets be explicitly granted Guest permissions (which has its own issues: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213016) 1. Public projects, which gives everyone full access to the source code 1. Public projects with the Repository visibility set to "Only Project Members": ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/2d98c9c3de6a308b3b978a8e337f9281/image.png) ... which also makes the **Releases** tab/page visible only to project members. ### Intended users Mostly [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager). ### Proposal One option might be to add a new permission option under **Settings > General > Visibility, project features, permissions** to control the visibility of Releases: ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/e8a5cde6dfb2e7a5b2663bed7faa8160/image.png) ### Further details One sticky detail that should probably be solved before this feature is delivered is how to reference and display Releases without exposing any tag data to users who shouldn't have access to repository information. This issue is described in detail here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213016#root-cause ### Availability & Testing ### Permissions and Security As mentioned above, it's important for projects that do **not** make the source code available to the public that we don't publish any tag or commit info through the **Releases** page. ### Documentation Yes, this feature will require updates to our documentation. ### What is the type of buyer? Up for discussion. Most of our Release functionality is Core at the moment, but perhaps this functionality is specialized enough to warrant being restricted to a higher tier. ### Links / references Some related discussions: - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/16328 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/issues/22165 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201770 ## Implementation plan - [x] Remove the Releases feature toggle from the behind the `split_operations_visibility_permissions` FF - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/99045
Example diff ```diff diff --git a/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/shared/permissions/components/settings_panel.vue b/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/shared/permissions/components/settings_panel.vue index a82f485bf44..91d645c524e 100644 --- a/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/shared/permissions/components/settings_panel.vue +++ b/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/shared/permissions/components/settings_panel.vue @@ -979,20 +979,20 @@ export default { name="project[project_feature_attributes][feature_flags_access_level]" /> - + - + - - + /> +
- [x] Update `ProjectPolicy` to decouple `release` permissions from `repository` permissions. - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/100170
Example diff ```diff diff --git a/app/policies/project_policy.rb b/app/policies/project_policy.rb index 9d121715d2c..2173b919a43 100644 --- a/app/policies/project_policy.rb +++ b/app/policies/project_policy.rb @@ -593,7 +593,6 @@ class ProjectPolicy < BasePolicy prevent :read_commit_status prevent :read_pipeline prevent :read_pipeline_schedule - prevent(*create_read_update_admin_destroy(:release)) prevent(*create_read_update_admin_destroy(:feature_flag)) prevent(:admin_feature_flags_user_lists) end ```
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality. It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes. Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*

title: Multi-project pipelines in Web IDE lead to 404
description:
### Problem to solve

When using multi-project pipelines, the Web IDE displays a link to a non-existent pipeline in the pipelines tab of the Web IDE. Clicking this link directs the user to a 404 page. See: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214214

### Proposal

In the pipelines area of GitLab, jobs related to a multi-project pipeline aren't clickable. We should remove the hyperlink to the jobs of a multi-project pipeline to prevent leading users to a 404.

title: Update all `GlLink`s with class="btn" in the Releases pages to use `GlButton` with `href`
description:
### Proposal

It is preferred to use `GlButton`s with an `href` attribute over `GlLink`s with `class="btn"` (source: https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C0GQHHPGW/p1588601058335600?thread_ts=1588600819.335400&cid=C0GQHHPGW (interal only)). `GlButton`s implement the Pajamas design specifications for buttons.

We should update all instances of `GlLink`s with `class="btn"` in `app/assets/javascripts/releases/**` to use `GlButton`.

Off the top of my head, the only instances of this are these two buttons on the main **Releases** page:

![image](/uploads/7ae30ebc38c4638d572f136fc6a338b6/image.png)

### Context

This is similar to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214242. I misunderstood the implementation of the buttons in the screenshot above when opening https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214242.

### Note about the `rel` attribute

When performing this conversion, we will need to manually add any `rel` attributes manually (if necessary) since `GlButton` does not automatically add this attribute like `GlLink` does (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/issues/762).

title: Search API merge_requests scope preload up/downvotes to improve performance
description:
# Summary

While working on the performance issue for the `merge_requests` scope, it was found that the queries for `upvotes` and `downvotes` do not get preloaded. However, during a call to `GET /api/v4/merge_requests` there is no N+1 for those calls. The Merge Requests API is using [`helpers ::Gitlab::IssuableMetadata`](/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/merge_requests.rb#L11) to preload the data before passing it to the present method. This helper could be utilized in the search API when models use the Awardable (or Issuable since it pulls Awardable in) concern. The models used by Search API found to use the concerns are: Issue, Note, Merge Request, and Snippet.

epic.title: Improve performance of Search API (Advanced) under load into next tier

title: Use Gitlab::Json class for flaky-report and helm3-client libs
description: Migrate `lib/quality/helm3_client` and `lib/rspec_flaky/report` to use the `Gitlab::Json` functionality instead of `JSON` to prevent the upcoming cop at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/211671 from failing.

title: Migrating merge request diffs to (and from) external storage holds open a database transaction
description:
### Summary

As noted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/1851#note_334699787 by @andrewn , we hold open a database transaction for the duration of a merge request diff migration to external storage (or back). This uses up a shared resource (pgbouncer connections) on GitLab.com.

### Steps to reproduce

* Migrate a very large diff to object storage
* Observe transaction timings

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Transaction is open for the duration of the copy to object storage

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Transaction should only be opened once the file has been created in object storage

### Possible fixes

The offending methods are [`MergeRequestDiff#migrate_files_to_external_storage!`](app/models/merge_request_diff.rb#L436) and [`MergeRequestDiff#migrate_files_to_database!`](app/models/merge_request_diff.rb#L465)

We *should* be able to remove the transactions, but particular care needs to be taken when reasoning about the behaviour of carrierwave to minimise the chances of data loss.

For migrating to external storage, we should:

* Create the external file
* Transactionally update the diffs
* (Best-effort) remove the external file if the update failed

For migrating back, we should:

* Transactionally update the diffs
* Remove the external file

title: Bad handling of too large Snippet files
description:
### Summary When creating a Snippet that is a) too large file, or b) has too many lines, the handling is far from being optimal. This is a regression after refactoring Snippet view to Vue | Before refactoring | After refactoring | | ------ | ------ | | ![Screenshot_2020-05-04_at_11.50.38](/uploads/cde7e3e35767cc24149f02633c4f795f/Screenshot_2020-05-04_at_11.50.38.png) | ![Screenshot_2020-05-04_at_11.51.10](/uploads/3bd44aa87c21670ced36979ef8ef8c26/Screenshot_2020-05-04_at_11.51.10.png) | :warning: The scope of this Issue has been re-defined and can be found in detail in [the relevant BE issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217434). ### Steps to reproduce * Create a new Snippet with too many lines (some `.log` or `.eslintcache` should be fine) * The view will simply tell `collapsed` or `too_large` without a possibility to get to the snippet's content ### Example Project Reproducible on gitlab.com ### What is the current *bug* behavior? There's no way to get to snippet's content ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? It should be possible to either load the content anyway or download the snippet. ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

title: Remove the fallback argument into a constant
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/29474/diffs#note_335693898

> Is the `fallback` ever set? I cannot see it used. Nor can I see it tested. I'm inclined to think that if the method is used consistently for counting things in redis then we'll probably always be happy for it to return `-1` as a fallback since this is always a good choice for a missing count. Further it seems that the underlying method calls imply this is only used for counts so I'd suggest we remove this argument. It would also be nice to remove because missing different styles for optional arguments in this way is kinda hard to read so it will be much cleaner without that argument.

title: CI linter: Extend errors messaging to include warnings
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

As we start deprecating CI features like extending only/except in shared templates https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release/tasks/-/issues/1315 it would be helpful to have a linter that helps users update their CI before it breaks. In order for this to be the most useful it should run on every pipeline and display them somewhere prominently.

<details>
  <summary>Expand to an example</summary>

Travis does this nicely, showing linting panel for every job, for example:

![Screen_Shot_2020-05-04_at_8.57.05_AM](/uploads/4c0d537bbc437646ca0d4a3d7086c10d/Screen_Shot_2020-05-04_at_8.57.05_AM.png)
</details>

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

### Proposal

For this MVC:
* Extend the [existing red banner for errors](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/590809a1eebf6b4cf41af6240d6f84e5/Screenshot_2020-05-08_at_20.36.56.png) to handle **errors** and also **warning**.
* Add warnings for these scenarios:
1. Using `rules` without `workflow: rules`; link to the [workflow:rules](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/pipelines.html#workflowrules) docs
1.  ~~Using `rules` and `only/except` in the same job is not supported~~

<details>
  <summary>(expand here for part of original proposal that is scoped to issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219431)</summary>

---

Store each offenses, one per line, as part of `YAML errors`, each identified with a severity, such as:
* error:
* warning:
* deprecation:

The format of a single line message could be:

```
<severity>: <job-name>: <message>
```

We could use this `yaml_errors` to also further refine the Build View and show this information there

Today, we would do these things:

* we just refine this box to present it differently on ~frontend based on severity
* we would need to add a small change to `Ci::Config` to allow easy way to generate `warning` and `deprecations`, join them together and persist as part of `ci_pipelines.yaml_errors`, including a context in above format

---

</details>

### Execution plan

1. Replace `has_yaml_errors?` with `config_error?` so that it won't use `yaml_errors` which will hold a different type of messages with this feature
1. Add mechanism inside `YamlProcessor` that allows to append warning messages as we do today with errors. Warning messages could be used to also describe deprecation warnings. We could distinguish them later.
    - Maybe we could extend `Gitlab::Config::Entry::Configurable` to have helper methods such as `add_warning`
1. Store multiple messages in `Ci::Pipeline#yaml_errors`. Ensure that `pipeline.errors` don't include warnings or deprecations.
1. Expose warnings in the frontend and API response for the Linter / Pipeline view - **this marks the 1st iteration, from user perspective**

---

In preparation to work on this maybe we need to first open a MR about replacing the use of `has_yaml_errors?` with `config_error?`. Then, we can make `yaml_errors` orthogonal to `failure_reason` as we may not have any failure reasons but warnings in `yaml_errors`.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

* Unit test changes - Yes
  * Ensure renaming does not affect existing behaviors - Error messages should still be displayed
  * Warnings message should show up where there is violation even if pipeline did not fail
* Integration test changes - Yes
  * Integration test API ~> UI:
    * Warnings and deprecation messages are recognized and displayed accordingly
    * In case pipeline did fail with a config error and there are also warning violation, show both error and warning in the banner.
* End-to-end test change - not required

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. title: Add LSIF to Go Auto DevOps gitlab-ci.yml
description:
## Problem to solve

Auto DevOps provides a great option to get started with GitLab CI with minimal work, however, if users want to add Code Intelligence, they have to explicitly reference the Auto DevOps template and add a code intelligence job. This is not intuitive or straightforward.

## Proposal

Code Intelligence should be on by default for projects using Auto DevOps, for all languages that have a usable LSIF indexer.

Add a `code intelligence` job to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Auto-DevOps.gitlab-ci.yml that uses `lsif-go`

As more LSIF indexers become `Ready` we can add support for those in future issues.

## Links

* Auto DevOps template https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Auto-DevOps.gitlab-ci.yml
* LSIF indexers https://lsif.dev/#LSIF_Indexers

title: GraphQL - Issue Resource - Global ID
description:
Good Morning,

Apologies for creating a new issue for this, but I'm banging my head against the wall :face_palm: and I can't seem to find an answer anywhere.

I'm currently using the GraphQL API and I'd like to assign labels to an issue (automated transitions for our workflow - webhooks). Looking at the getting started documentation, this can be achieved by creating a note with a `quick action`. [Related Documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/getting_started.html#creation-mutations).

To create a note, I need to get the `ID` (Global) of the issue, however the current `Issue` resource doesnt include this and only returns the `IID` back and I can't seem to find a route to be able to obtain this ID.

Looking through the Documentation, it doesn't seem that I can report this as a `bug` as the ID field isn't documented for the issue resource. However, it does feel like this should probably be included.

Thank you in advance!

Relates to #216087

title: Improve CI minutes batch reset error messages
description:
When a batch that resets the [CI minutes fails](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/ci/minutes/batch_reset_service.rb#L36) we display the following message

`1000 namespace shared runner minutes were not reset and the transaction was rolled back. Namespace Ids: [1734561, 1734562, 1734563, 1734564, 1734565, 1734566, 1734567, 1734569, 1734570, 1734571]`

In this error message we don't know:
- what error actually happen? We should display the `ActiveRecord::ActiveRecordError` message as well as adding more information to it like that the batches failed to be reset.
- what was last ID not reset? We should instead display the first and last ID of the failing batch, rather than the first 10 namespaces.

title: Update secrets analyzer in support of move to separate vendored template
description:
In support of [Move secret detection into its own vendored template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/207990), we will need to update the [secrets analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/).

At a minimum, we will need to update what gets output to the json report. It currently outputs a `gl-sast-report.json` file, but the name of that will likely need to change as well.

In order to best provide backwards compatibility, we should consider releasing this change as version `3.0.0` of the analyzer so that self-hosted customers on previous versions will continue to be able to run the `2.x` versions of `secrets`.

This will also require changes to the following repositories:
- [x] common - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/92
- [x] security-reports-schema - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas /-/merge_requests/27

epic.title: Secret Detection as Standalone Scan Type

title: Backfill wiki page metadata
description:
Now that wiki page metadata exists as a thing, we need to backfill the DB so we can reliably make use of it, without triggering any wiki activity events.

This requires:

- adding a new background migration
- iterating over all projects with wikis, and adding them to a queue for processing
- pulling each unprocessed project from the queue, going over all wiki pages and calling `WikiPage::Meta.find_or_create`
  - this method is safe to call on pages we already have meta records for
  - it might be good to find ways to create metadata in batches, rather than one at a time
  - to save redundant work, we want to avoid processing the same page/project twice.

The job is complete when every page created before the migration was first run has been processed.

It might be useful to collect statistics about wikis before we start the migration (number of pages, etc).

title: Snippet invalid_path for file name error
description:
### Summary

Since the introduction of versioned snippets, there is currently a problem if a Snippet has a filename that will result in an invalid git path, e.g. using `http://test.my.url:3000/breaks/things`.

The error is [raised within Gitaly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/blob/HEAD/ruby/lib/gitlab/git/index.rb#L138) (via the Rugged gem) and has three different impacts which we need to address:

**1. Creating Snippets**:

Creating a Snippet in the GitLab UI this results in an `"invalid path: http://test.my.url:3000/breaks/things"` error being displayed to the user

**2. Updating Snippets**:

A generic `"Error updating the snippet"` message is displayed when updating an existing Snippet

**3. Migrating Snippets to versioned**:

Migration of existing Snippets in the [backfill migration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/background_migration/backfill_snippet_repositories.rb) fails in this scenario

### What we need to do

We can potentially address these issues in the following way:

1. Creating Snippets - catch the error and display a more friendly message, e.g. `Invalid file name used`

2. Updating Snippets - catch this error and return a useful message to the user so they know what they have to address to proceed

3. Migrating Snippets - catch this error and `parameterize` (or some other equivalent?) the file name so that it becomes valid and the migration can succeed.

This can be handled in two separate MRs, one for create/update and the other for the migration with the priority being the migration solution due to it's current impact.

### Steps to reproduce

Create or update an existing snippet accordingly, with the file name `http://test.my.url:3000/breaks/things`

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

1. Renders message from Gitaly/Rugged
2. Unhelpful message delivered to users
3. Migration fails

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

1. Appropriate message used
2. Appropriate message used
3. Migration succeeds

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2020-04-30_at_16.26.45](/uploads/5de3f133ed0b961063ba921a8a6b9bf5/Screenshot_2020-04-30_at_16.26.45.png)

title: Skipped tests are included in total % of tests ran
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

The JUnit report is counting skipped tests in the total for tests ran which is not necessarily accurate.

### Steps to reproduce

(How one can reproduce the issue - this is very important)

1. Create a [project](https://gitlab.com/jheimbuck_gl/skipped-tests/pipelines/131057123/test_report) with some unit tests that are skipped.
2. Navigate to the Tests tab for a pipeline that has skipped tests.

### Example Project

[Validation Project](https://gitlab.com/jheimbuck_gl/skipped-tests) from initial write-up.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Success rate is calculated as Passed tests / total tests. This includes the failed, errors, skipped and passed.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Success rate should calculate on passed tests / executed tests. This should include failed, errors and passed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

title: WebIDE: Migrate Create New File/Folder modal to use GlModal
description:
The New File/Folder modal currently uses the old Deprecated modal. Migrate it to use the new `GlModal`. 

![Screenshot_2020-04-30_at_5.49.26_PM](/uploads/52dfbfc08268a273f63fd9a49cc5d3c5/Screenshot_2020-04-30_at_5.49.26_PM.png)

Reason for change: `GlModal` adds modals as a child to `body`, whereas `DeprecatedModal` adds modal as a child to the container itself. When a modal is added in the container, it inherits the styles of its container, which causes a lot of problems with the dark theme.

title: Remove `update_project_statistics_after_commit` feature flag
description:
This issue is a follow-up from introducing the `update_project_statistics_after_commit` feature flag, where we look into removing it.

Removing the feature flag makes updating project statistics to run in the `after_commit` queue so that it does affect the transaction given that it's currently prone to timing out.

With [Efficient Counters](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/24469) we are going to solve the problem of timeouts.

title: Clean up optimized_elasticsearch_indexes_project feature flag
description:
Eliminate the `optimized_elasticsearch_indexes_project` FF after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30612 is merged an the optimized version of the query is verified in production.

Steps:

- Remove the feature flag condition in `ee/app/models/ee/application_setting.rb`
- Remove the feature flag specific `context` and inline the shared examples (`examples for elasticsearch_indexes_project?`) in `ee/spec/models/application_setting_spec.rb`

title: Investigate side effect of empty hash in redis counters, impact in version app
description:
Check the impact of having empty hash for any Redis counters. Follow up issue from the MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/29474#note_333789444

At the moment of opening this issue we have this payload for redis counters

```ruby
Gitlab::UsageData.usage_counters
=> {:wiki_pages_create=>0,
 :wiki_pages_update=>0,
 :wiki_pages_delete=>0,
 :web_ide_commits=>0,
 :web_ide_views=>0,
 :web_ide_merge_requests=>0,
 :web_ide_previews=>0,
 :snippet_comment=>0,
 :commit_comment=>0,
 :merge_request_comment=>0,
 :snippet_create=>0,
 :snippet_update=>0,
 :navbar_searches=>0,
 :cycle_analytics_views=>0,
 :productivity_analytics_views=>0,
 :source_code_pushes=>0,
 :merge_request_create=>0,
 :design_management_designs_create=>0,
 :design_management_designs_update=>0,
 :design_management_designs_delete=>0,
 :licenses_list_views=>0}
```

Each redis counter brings one group of counters with keys and merges it to the final hash

For example UsageDataCounters

```
{:wiki_pages_create=>0,
 :wiki_pages_update=>0,
 :wiki_pages_delete=>0,
}
```

We want to understand what is the effect of not having this keys, it will break version app?

title: Sometimes merge request diffs that are stored externally fail to set the `external_diff_store` column
description:
https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1560052/?referrer=gitlab_plugin

This causes the code review tab `Changes` in a merge request to not load. 

```
Errno::ENOENT: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - /var/opt/gitlab/gitlab-rails/shared/external-diffs/merge_request_diffs/mr-55383568/diff-84831695
  gitlab_uploader.rb:89:in `initialize'
    File.open(path, "rb") if path
  gitlab_uploader.rb:89:in `open'
    File.open(path, "rb") if path
  gitlab_uploader.rb:89:in `open'
    File.open(path, "rb") if path
  merge_request_diff.rb:424:in `opening_external_diff'
    external_diff.open do |file|
  gitlab/metrics/instrumentation.rb:161:in `block in opening_external_diff'
    .measure { super }
...
(150 additional frame(s) were not displayed)

Errno::ENOENT: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - /var/opt/gitlab/gitlab-rails/shared/external-diffs/merge_request_diffs/mr-55383568/diff-84831695
```

**Workaround**:


1. Navigate to the Merge request
1. Click on `Commits` tab next to `Changes`
1. Click on a specific commit and wait for the file to load
1. Then click on the `Changes` tab

title: On 404 "Sign out and sign back in" action is undefined
description:
## Description

Noticed on `.com`.

- Sign in to GitLab
- Visit a page you don't have access to (like `/edit` of a project you aren't a maintainer of)
- Click "Sign out and sign back in"
- The user is redirected to `/sign_out` which does not exist...

![20200428_404_sign_out_bug](/uploads/9f8b6ccf39df33185538adeaba24d0a4/20200428_404_sign_out_bug.mp4)

## Expectation

I'd expect this link to behave more like the "Sign out" button on the main GitLab nav bar.

![Screen_Shot_2020-04-29_at_2.05.03_PM](/uploads/3096067b969fa67615ae6d1754f46cd4/Screen_Shot_2020-04-29_at_2.05.03_PM.png)

Notice that the URL is `users/sign_out` and it looks like a POST request is necessary.

However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Release notes
GitLab now records an audit event when the protected status of an environment is updated. This is helpful for auditing any changes to the deployment process, since protected environments are typically used for deploying code to special environments such as production.

### Problem to solve

Customers using [protected environments](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/protected_environments.html) need to be able to audit when protections were added or removed.

### Proposal

title: Issuable listings: Filter by label=Any with custom sorting results in API error
description:
### Problem
At any MR\Issue listing pages (Code Review Analytics, Issues, MRs)
When filtering by `label=Any` with custom sorting (e.g. `review_time` or `milestone_due_date`), the API responds with an error:

![image](/uploads/4b79d0a4b8f7625b2884f8b2e4fe87bd/image.png)

**Sample request:**

https://gitlab.com/api/v4/analytics/code_review?project_id=278964&label_name[]=Any&page=1

Other labels (including the `label=None` option) work as expected.

### Sentry report

https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1586422

### Investigation

[Any label filtering adds implicit grouping](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/concerns/issuable.rb#L120) to the query, but doesn't add custom sorting attribute to grouping, so as a result Postgres blames that sorting attribute is not present in SELECT or GROUP part of query. 

This error can happen not only at CRA but anywhere where custom sorting + label=Any is used. E.g. [Issues listing](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues?label_name%5B%5D=Any&sort=milestone) or [MRs listing](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests?scope=all&utf8=%E2%9C%93&state=opened&label_name[]=Any)

You can manually recreate the bug at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues by using label=Any and sorting=Milestone Due Date

### Fix Proposal

[Here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/concerns/issuable.rb#L292) is how we handle it for other cases, so we'll need to adjust `any_label` scope to be aware of custom sorting too.
